Award.AwardTitle: Towards a General Automatic Reasoning Framework for Networked Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
ECCS-1002258
Huaiyu Dai
North Carolina State University
Towards a General Automatic Reasoning Framework for Networked Systems

ABSTRACT

Intellectual Merit: The objective of this research is to develop a general and flexible framework for automatic inference in networked systems that can admit wide applications and provide desired tradeoff between accuracy and efficiency, while allowing simple and distributed implementation. Given that exact interference is generally intractable whereas the widely-adopted mean field approach is limited in inference quality, the approach of this research is to explore the structured variational methods to bridge the gap and allow flexible tradeoff among various potentially conflicting goals, which can be tuned according to the needs and available resources of applications. Various models, dependency structures, and inference algorithms will be considered in this variational inference framework, together with efficient distributed implementation. An associated research line is to design automatic clustering schemes that ideally can match the needs of inference tasks while being easy to implement in a distributed manner. The interaction between the clustering and inference layer will be explored to achieve better performance and adaptivity.

Broader Impacts: This project contributes fundamental concepts, designs, analytical tools and software towards building a general and systematic framework for automatic reasoning in large-scale networked systems, such as sensor networks and cyber-physical systems. The expected outcome can be applied in diverse areas including security, transportation, medicine, energy, manufacturing and many others. Through suitable modification, the proposed distributed clustering algorithms also admit wide applications in various areas of network science and engineering. The multi-disciplinary nature of the proposed research also lends itself to cross-disciplinary education and well-rounded training of a future IT workforce. Special efforts are taken to encourage the participation of students from underrepresented groups. Various channels are pursued to disseminate research findings, developed software, and educational materials to industry and the broader public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Large-scale networked systems of intelligent devices are playing an increasingly important role in protecting the nation's critical infrastructures as well as satisfying people's desire for better life. The objective of this project is to develop a general and flexible framework to facilitate information collection, processing, and inference in networked systems. Through this project, four major research outcomes have been achieved towards our goal. First, we explore novel designs based on non-reversible Markov chains for distributed consensus, a basic building block for distributed computing and inference, and improve the convergence performance by an order of magnitude. With appropriate modification, our designs can be extended to address a large class of computing and inferencing problems. Some important applications include coordination and cooperation of autonomous agents, load balancing in distributed and parallel computing, and various applications in wireless ad hoc and sensor networks. Second, we explore efficient protocol design for in-network information fusion and processing subject to noisy communications, and design a general protocol for computing any divisible functions, which constitute the main body of interest for large-scale distributed applications. The merits of this general protocol include: 1) it provides a benchmark to evaluate various functions; 2) its bottleneck analysis motivates further studies on more efficient specific protocols. Third, based on a new performance metric, mobile conductance, we develop a general methodology for the study of information spreading in mobile networks, which can accommodate various mobility models, different combinations of transmission range and moving speed under a unified framework. Finally, we develop a message-passing framework for distributed inference, which exploits structured variational approaches to achieve flexible tradeoffs among various performance metrics including inference quality, execution time, computational complexity, and energy consumption, and can be tuned for specific application needs. The developed design framework and associated analytical tools are general and find wide applications in large-scale networked systems. This project is cross-disciplinary in nature, lying in the interface of networking, wireless communications, signal processing and distributed computing, making an impact in all these areas.

This project has contributed to education through its impact on graduate course content in wireless communications and signal processing, through research seminars and invited talks, and through participation in annual Engineering Open House, Senior Design Day, and Undergraduate Research Symposium at NCSU. This project has partially supported one postdoc researcher, five PhD students and two MS students. Researchers and students who worked on this project developed research skills in theoretical analysis (in particular related to network science and graph theory) and algorithm design, as well as experience with emerging communication technologies such as energy harvesting and cognitive radio.
